PRICE 5 CENTS

Hopkins Science Club To
Hold Meeting Tonight
The Johns Hopkins Science Club,
formed last year, will hold its organization meeting tonight a 7:15
P.M., in Remsen 301. This club was
organized as an interested group
of students who desired to correlate
the field of Chemistry, Biology and
Physics, from the experimental
points of view. Dr. John C. Hubbard, Professor of Physics, and Dr.
R. P. Cowles, Professor of Biology,
are the advisors of the group.
The officers elected last year
are:
Augustus Fink, President.
William Charney, Secretary.
Tony Vittello, Treasurer.
All interested students are invited to attend the meeting.

Campus of the Hopkins to discuss the
problems which face the young people of the country today.
When the session of the American
Youth Congress is convened, three
questions of primary importance will
be introduced and debated:
I The problem of world peace, the
violations of which threaten the destruction of the yciuth of the entire
world as well as of America.
2. The problem of securing an education and of finding jobs.
3. The problem of preserving the
Bill of Rights of the Constitution of
the United States.
World peace is still the most challenging and immedate problem facing mankind today. War is today in
imminent probability, in spite of Willie
Hearst's deceiving assurance to the
contrary. When the war does come, it
will be the youth of America who will
be drawn in at once. It is they who
will be the most closely and quickly
affected.
Tuesday appeared an editorial in
the NEWS-LETTER decrying the fact
that the now-almost-forgotten election campaign featured more violations of civil liberty than ever before in a similar length of time. These
infractions of our traditionally American rights of free speech and freethought are spreading throughout
America—in academic fields, in industry, in every phase of life—Gag
legislation and teachers' oath bills
are prevalent and increasing; terrorism and violence is being used widely
to suppress every kind of individual
freedom. So far as America itself is
concerned, no problem is more pressing than that of our fast disappearing
freedom of conscience.
To the individual person, especially
to youth, nothing is more immediate
than the problem of securing a living.
Hundreds of thousands of young people are coming into their own each
year in a jobless America. The value
of the actions taken by the government to prevent that situation is debatable. That a tremendous unemployment exists among youth cannot be
doubted. That something must be done

some young men go to college not
to gain an education, but primarily
to fill in four years of their lives. He
Went on to explain that many men,
knowing that it will be easier to procure a job with the background of a
college education, go to universities
all over the country. Thus, they do
not seek for a higher education, but
tise college as simply a bridge from
one period of their lives to another.
This fact explains the tremendous
overcrowding at state universities
throughout the country. At private institutions such as Johns Hopkins more
discrimination is made in one choice
of students. There is a weeding out
of one type of those students who
Merely go to college with the aim
mentioned above; that is to fill a four
years gap in his life before he is able
to secure a position.

The course follows four graduated
steps—diagnosis demonstration
practice, and performance. Practice Is
left largely to the individual student
and is a regular part of her outside
preparation work for the course.
Progress or lack of progress is demonstrated in class-room performances.
For the sake of comparison, each student again will record her voice at
the end of the course.
One act plays, debating, and similar activities keep emphasis on speech
as one of the main objectives. Upper
classmen are not required to enroll,
but the poor freshmen have no choice;
they can't even talk themselves out
of taking the course.

Leading the herd in division "B,"
Delta Upsilon added another victory
to its growing list. The D. U. used
thirteen players, and easily gained a
12-0 victory over Phi Epsilon Pi. Attempting to find a winning combination the Phi Eps made several substitutions, but the attack and defensive
of Delta Upsilon repelled the losers'
efforts. McShane continued to star
for the D. U. five by scoring both
touchdowns for the victorious team.
0.1(.0.

Wins 24-18

Omicron Kappa Omicron kept in
pace with Delta Upsilon by topping
Kappa Sigma 24-18. Kappa Sigs furnished unexpected opposition, and the
conflict was in doubt until the final
whistle. On a series of passes and
running plays, Frome, Almquist, and
McGovern scored the losing squad
markers. However, the combined play
of Hartman and Thaler netted four
scores which gave O.K.O. a six-point
victory.
K.A. Upsets Phi Sigs
In another game, Kappa Alpha upset Phi Sigma Delta 18-14. The Phi
Sigs were tied with O.K.O. for runnerup honors in division "B," but the inspiring play of K.A. toppled P.S.D.
out of second place. Phi Sigma held a
14-12 margin at the half, but Kappa
Alpha came back to score the winning marker. Reynolds again played
an important part in K.A.'s triumph.
He tallied two six-pointers, and also
played good on the defense. Katz
made a creditable showing for the defeated frat along with Goldstein and
Rothstein.

At Baltimore Y. M. H. A. Gym

Successful
The intramural athletic program,
organized and directed by the Athletic
Department, is enjoying unprecedented success. The zealous enthusiasm
and the keen rivalry manifested in the
current football competition indicate
clearly that intramural sport at Hopkins is encroaching dangerously upon
the popularity of intercollegiate athletics.
The primary purpose of any athletic
program here is to serve the recreative
needs of as many students as possible.
That great progress has been made in
attaining this aim is evidenced by the
fact that more than 85 percent of the
student body were participants in
some athletic pursuit last year.

Great Progress
In Recent Years
The significance of so expansive a
program is more fully appreciated,
when we realize that but three years
ago, there was no gymnasium, and
that the disinterested and half-hearted

supervision, intramural athletics have
ascended the ladder of popularity at
the Hopkins.

Hopkins Science Club To
Hold Meeting Tonight
The Johns Hopkins Science Club,
formed last year, will hold its organization meeting tonight a 7:15
P.M., in Remsen 301. This club was
organized as an interested group
of students who desired to correlate
the field of Chemistry, Biology and
Physics, from the experimental
points of view. Dr. John C. Hubbard, Professor of Physics, and Dr.
R. P. Cowles, Professor of Biology,
are the advisors of the group.
The officers elected last year
are:
Augustus Fink, President.
William Charney, Secretary.
Tony Vittello, Treasurer.
All interested students are invited to attend the meeting.

Campus of the Hopkins to discuss the
problems which face the young people of the country today.
When the session of the American
Youth Congress is convened, three
questions of primary importance will
be introduced and debated:
I The problem of world peace, the
violations of which threaten the destruction of the yciuth of the entire
world as well as of America.
2. The problem of securing an education and of finding jobs.
3. The problem of preserving the
Bill of Rights of the Constitution of
the United States.
World peace is still the most challenging and immedate problem facing mankind today. War is today in
imminent probability, in spite of Willie
Hearst's deceiving assurance to the
contrary. When the war does come, it
will be the youth of America who will
be drawn in at once. It is they who
will be the most closely and quickly
affected.
Tuesday appeared an editorial in
the NEWS-LETTER decrying the fact
that the now-almost-forgotten election campaign featured more violations of civil liberty than ever before in a similar length of time. These
infractions of our traditionally American rights of free speech and freethought are spreading throughout
America—in academic fields, in industry, in every phase of life—Gag
legislation and teachers' oath bills
are prevalent and increasing; terrorism and violence is being used widely
to suppress every kind of individual
freedom. So far as America itself is
concerned, no problem is more pressing than that of our fast disappearing
freedom of conscience.
To the individual person, especially
to youth, nothing is more immediate
than the problem of securing a living.
Hundreds of thousands of young people are coming into their own each
year in a jobless America. The value
of the actions taken by the government to prevent that situation is debatable. That a tremendous unemployment exists among youth cannot be
doubted. That something must be done
is obvious, for the energy of youth

some young men go to college not
to gain an education, but primarily
to fill in four years of their lives. He
Went on to explain that many men,
knowing that it will be easier to procure a job with the background of a
college education, go to universities
all over the country. Thus, they do
not seek for a higher education, but
tise college as simply a bridge from
one period of their lives to another.
This fact explains the tremendous
overcrowding at state universities
throughout the country. At private institutions such as Johns Hopkins more
discrimination is made in one choice
of students. There is a weeding out
of one type of those students who
Merely go to college with the aim
mentioned above; that is to fill a four
years gap in his life before he is able
to secure a position.

The course follows four graduated
steps—diagnosis demonstration
practice, and performance. Practice Is
left largely to the individual student
and is a regular part of her outside
preparation work for the course.
Progress or lack of progress is demonstrated in class-room performances.
For the sake of comparison, each student again will record her voice at
the end of the course.
One act plays, debating, and similar activities keep emphasis on speech
as one of the main objectives. Upper
classmen are not required to enroll,
but the poor freshmen have no choice;
they can't even talk themselves out
of taking the course.

Troy, N.Y. (ACP)—If you want to
graduate from Russell Sage College,
you now have to talk yourself out.
This year, for the first time, all
freshmen are required to enroll in
speech courses. Each pupil receives a
first-hand opportunity to "hear herself as others hear her," for phonograph records are made of her voice
to help her in diagnosing her own
speech weaknesses.

Leading the herd in division "B,"
Delta Upsilon added another victory
to its growing list. The D. U. used
thirteen players, and easily gained a
12-0 victory over Phi Epsilon Pi. Attempting to find a winning combination the Phi Eps made several substitutions, but the attack and defensive
of Delta Upsilon repelled the losers'
efforts. McShane continued to star
for the D. U. five by scoring both
touchdowns for the victorious team.
0.1(.0.

Wins 24-18

Omicron Kappa Omicron kept in
pace with Delta Upsilon by topping
Kappa Sigma 24-18. Kappa Sigs furnished unexpected opposition, and the
conflict was in doubt until the final
whistle. On a series of passes and
running plays, Frome, Almquist, and
McGovern scored the losing squad
markers. However, the combined play
of Hartman and Thaler netted four
scores which gave O.K.O. a six-point
victory.
K.A. Upsets Phi Sigs
In another game, Kappa Alpha upset Phi Sigma Delta 18-14. The Phi
Sigs were tied with O.K.O. for runnerup honors in division "B," but the inspiring play of K.A. toppled P.S.D.
out of second place. Phi Sigma held a
14-12 margin at the half, but Kappa
Alpha came back to score the winning marker. Reynolds again played
an important part in K.A.'s triumph.
He tallied two six-pointers, and also
played good on the defense. Katz
made a creditable showing for the defeated frat along with Goldstein and
Rothstein.

At Baltimore Y. M. H. A. Gym

Successful
The intramural athletic program,
organized and directed by the Athletic
Department, is enjoying unprecedented success. The zealous enthusiasm
and the keen rivalry manifested in the
current football competition indicate
clearly that intramural sport at Hopkins is encroaching dangerously upon
the popularity of intercollegiate athletics.
The primary purpose of any athletic
program here is to serve the recreative
needs of as many students as possible.
That great progress has been made in
attaining this aim is evidenced by the
fact that more than 85 percent of the
student body were participants in
some athletic pursuit last year.

Great Progress
In Recent Years
The significance of so expansive a
program is more fully appreciated,
when we realize that but three years
ago, there was no gymnasium, and
that the disinterested and half-hearted

supervision, intramural athletics have
ascended the ladder of popularity at
the Hopkins.

Alpha Delta Phi copped a 14-2 win

Three Weeks Remain
With three weeks left of touch
football Delta Upsilon is pacing division "B". In division "A' Phi Lambda
Phi and Sigma Phi Epsilon are knotted
for top honors. Unless one or the
other is conquered before November
24, the battle between these !rats on
that date will decide the victor of
division "A".

Psi; Delta Phi versus Sigma Phi
Epsilon.

Theta Pi; Tau Alpha Phi versus Phi
Psi.
Wednesday—Tau Alpha Omega versus Sigma Phi Epsilon; Alpha Epsilon versus Delta Phi.
Thursday—Phi Sigma versus Delta
Upsilon; Kappa Alpha versus Alpha
Delta Phi.
